Here is a fact, “can you hear me now” is a thing in most desert environments.  No TMobile, Verizon or MAbell will work when you need it.  Most people can walk a mile in no time, but the second mile isn’t that fast because heat will dehydrate you and your brain needs lots of water to operate.  Desperation and fear will drain more water and diminish brain activity faster.  Heat Stroke?  Heat Exhaustion? Death, so drink water weeks before and take extra water

Many years ago went "elk" hunting with a friend.  I went to go get the jeep, while he "field dressed" the animal.  I walked for about ten/fifteen minutes to where I thought we had left the Jeep.  As I was walking, I came upon another hunter.  Was I surprised when it turned out to be my friend.  I had walked back in a circle without realizing it.  Somebody once told me, if you walk on unfamiliar ground long enough, your dominate foot (left or right) will cause you to do that - walk in a circle.  BTW - when I got back to where he was, he asked - "Where's the Jeep?"

replies.context:

Explain to me why you have elk in quotations. I'm leaving on a Wyoming "elk" hunt in October and really want to make sure my grammar is in place to tell the story when I get back.

If planning to hike in the wilderness, please consider first getting a Technician Amateur Radio license and taking a handy talkie (HT) programmed with local repeater and national calling frequencies. Doing so is an excellent safety net against cell phones not working in the area, since it's highly likely that the HT can connect to a repeater for emergency help.

replies.context: Satellite cell phones are cheap to rent.
Excellent point!
You are better off with a Spot or an InReach they are inexpensive, you have better coverage, and they are purpose-built for emergencies.  I wouldn't be my life on a repeater being available.

Yes, either satellite communications device is a nice choice--although many times more expensive than a good HT.
"I wouldn't be my life on a repeater being available."
Preprogramming for local repeaters will indicate their availability and distance. Of course, terrain make a difference, but this would all be worked out ahead of time.

I've hiked in the desert in May, which is still a very hot month. We had lots of water! I drank 3 quarts of water that morning before I started the hike. I had close to 2 gallons more to get me thru the day. We also let the park rangers know where we were hiking and at what time we expected to be back. Hiking in extreme conditions can be a cherished memory, or it can be your doom. Please prepare properly so that it is the former.

A) If you or your girlfriend can't make it, you probably shouldn't go.
B) Remember where you're going so you know how to make it back.
C) Worrying about water or thinking you have to have it slows you down. 
D) Take breaks, reconnect your thoughts and bearings.    
E) Keep a bandana around your neck.
F) If you die, it's because you only failed yourself.  That's no excuse.
G) Your body is set up to do miraculous things, don't undercut yourself.
I carry enough gear on a day hike to survive easily for 48 to 72 hours. I carry a map and compass , at least a half gallon of water and a water straw to purify water from any source.

context: With that heat wave going on in California, why do people go hiking in places where they are far away from any help or civilization?  It makes no sense to me.  Stay home....go to the beach.  Go sit by the pool.  Save the hiking for the cooler weather, for gosh's sake.

Such a shame.  It's diffucult to know what to do in those situations when water might be available just over that next hill - I get it.  The dry heat pulls the water out of you with every breath.  I got myself stuck in the flour-like sand of the Mojave roughly 8 miles from the nearest paved road and spent 22 hours alone in 110+ daytime temps.  You want to start walking out but I rememberd the mantra "always stay with your vehicle" which saved me when a railway employee spotted it while staging a repair in the only remote rail-yard in the basin.  Lucky beyong belief.  Wish this young man could have shared in that luck.
You got to be prepared. Have plenty of supplies and always track your location. Prayers to the family

context:
You have 2 days at best in the desert to survive with no water. 
Find shade in the daytime and rest. Search dig for water in the mornings and night. 
Don't believe the myth a barrel cactus can give u water.

replies.context: Dont believe that you can dig for water and find it in the desert , you will DIE before you find  water .
You can find a dried up stream bed and dig in low spots sometimes you can find water a few feet down. But it needs to be purified first.
Unless you dug in a sewer, the water that wells up is safe enough to drink.
There are pathogens in the water it needs to be boiled you can get sick.
Dude i live by the Gila river in AZ , at 500 yards away we had to drill 75 feet for our well

Be prepared - is what we learned in boy scouts and it has stayed with me to this day - I hike a lot in the mountains of Utah - my pack has lots of things I hope I won’t need but just in case I carry an extra 5-7 lbs if gear - water is so critical I always over do it - and have returns to my car with half of the water not used - causes me pain to hear these stories - I may one day die in the mountains as well but until that day I will prepare as best I can.

context:
Always take at least twice the amount of water that you think that you need.  
And always be on the way back when you use 1/3 of your water.  This way you will have a reserve.  
Marking your starting point with a GPS is a great idea.
Letting someone know where you are going and when you will be back saves lives.
3 days, that's all it takes, just 3 days without water and you're dead.

It's easy to get turned around even on a trail.  You should stop every so often and look back down the path if you have to backtrack.  Paths can look different when going in the opposite direction you've been going.  There can be a fork that you didn't notice.

replies.context: Trail blazing isn't a bad idea either.  Mark where you've been and the direction you're going in.  It makes it easier to find your way back and for people to find you.
Trail "blazing"... he died in the heat... I get it... funny.

context:
Failing to prepare even for the most minor of walks or hikes is preparing your funeral. 
Nature is unforgiving and doesn’t care who you are. 
First rule of survival though is NEVER split up. 90% of the survival situations the person who said “let me go get help…” is often the first victim. 
Best thing is to stay put. Wait for rescue.

This happens every year.  Person goes on a hike without water and succumbs to the heat.  Camel packs and canteens are available in every store that caters to hiking.  
Out west, especially states like Texas, New Mexico, Arizona, Utah, Nevada, and also southern California if you go hiking without water during the summer you are just asking for trouble.
Cause of death: weak girlfriend on hike.
I have hiked Death Valley.  Most people aren't prepared for the quantity of water that must be carried.

replies.context: This is nowhere near death valley.

context: A small roll of reflective duct tape has many uses in a pack, including marking where you are going, and where you have been. After hiking in N. Arizona in 110 heat and seeing day hikers out without pack, water or a hat, these stories don't surprise me anymore.

context:
"The temperature in the area had soared to 114 degrees..."
In case you don't know, that is dangerous heat to be hiking in if you're not prepared. It takes more then two bottles of water and a CLIFF bar.  My  wife and I went camping/hiking at the end of July in Texas and, 90% of my back pack was nothing but water. BE PREPARED.

replies.context: And get an ATV.
It seems to me to be miserable heat to be hiking in - even if you are prepared...
It can be but we like it.
To each his own, I guess.  I would rather be indoors in the AC... :)
It also takes electrolytes. Water is a must, but will flush out the minerals needed to stay alert if too much is consumed. I always take an estimate amount of water needed plus electrolyte packs.
We also had power-aid and tea-packs.

This is sadly NOT the first nor the last time this will occur. 
I once had an heated discussion with a father of 3 and his wife in a parking lot at RMNP. They were leaving the trailhead for a hike at 2PM on a summer day. Shorts, sneakers, no backpacks no water, no food. I asked them where they were headed - Ypsilon lake, 8 mile hike at high altitude. I offered to give him my extra water and food, repeatedly but he refused. I advised against being in the mountains when electrical storms are likely. I also mentioned that my nephew and I had just come from there and we had started out at at 7am. They left. 
Don't minimize the danger of wilderness. There is no doordash, there is no uber this is not a disney movie. Bad things can happen EVEN if you are prepared.
